text: I did a demo with Rock content and it started at 12k/year with an 8k set up. So it's pretty large scale.

text:
Definitely. This is most of what we do at Message Lab. Sounds overly simple, but you have to start with what you want to achieve. Is the objective really just growth of the core owned channel? Or are you hoping that with growth comes engagement and some form of marketing/business conversion? Also, what's your channel plan to drive traffic? All organic or mix of paid and organic?

I'd always caution to under promise and over deliver on numbers (and their associated value) with a new property.  Also keep in mind that traffic (users, pageviews, etc.) are just signals - we typically don't like to make them meaningful ends in themselves. But if the objective is building awareness of your brand through content - then channel growth (e.g. new and return visitors from search, social, etc. etc.) may be more impactful.
[5:49 PM] We tend to look at pageviews either as a signal of interest in a category/topic/type or the result of some effective campaign that drove users. However, if 90 percent of those users bailed within 10 seconds, hard to say those were all good pageviews. You may be using bounce to assess this but bounce, while it has its uses, can be tricky.

text:
These are all fantastic tips. <@U0216ELKLQY>, that's my overall plan to keep things general until we see what we can accomplish and get some content amplification efforts going, but our leadership team likes numbers and metrics. :woman-facepalming:

<@U021QMNMQ68> Thanks for the tool. I'll check nit out.

<@U01T8TVMUSD> Thanks for the advice. Right now we're focusing on creating awareness and driving leads, as we also build the business. Certainly a mix of paid and organic. But the organic will take a while to grow.

elements.text: , that's my overall plan to keep things general until we see what we can accomplish and get some content amplification efforts going, but our leadership team likes numbers and metrics.
Thanks for the tool. I'll check nit out.
Thanks for the advice. Right now we're focusing on creating awareness and driving leads, as we also build the business. Certainly a mix of paid and organic. But the organic will take a while to grow.

text: Hi <@U022P09NXS7>, I agree with Will that engagement will be more crucial that simply page metrics. Work on spelling out a long-term strategy for the execs. You could look at some successful competitor blogs and might be able to pull some numbers on how long it took them to get to that point (years). Once you get some traction, one metric that always helped me as a blog manager was site entrances through our blogs. Once filtered for this, I could provide good metrics on what how our readers were engaging with the content and other parts of the website.
